MANU DIBANGO

On 12th December 1933, Emmanuel N'Djoké "Manu" Dibango was born into a musical Protestant Christian household in Douala Cameroon. Here he discovered his talent for music as he sang at the local church where his mother was the choir leader.

In 1949, Dibango was sent to continue his studies in France at the age of 15. At the age of 17, he started taking piano lessons and thereafter he learnt the saxophone. He joined a jazz band with noted Cameroonian guitarist and composer Francis Bebey and soon became a recognized entity within the local jazz circuit.

In 1959, Dibango moved to Brussels where he learnt to play the vibraphone and it was then he started realising his ambition of fusing musical genres by merging jazz with African music.

In 1960, Dibango toured Europe with ‘African Jazz’, a band led by a Congolese musician Joseph Kabesele who shared Dibango’s interest in musical fusion. After the tour, he followed Kabesele to Democratic Republic of Congo and stayed there for 3 years.

In 1963, Dibango returned to his motherland Cameroon where he established his own band and continued to broaden his knowledge of African styles. Dibango returned to France in 1965, and in 1972, he released a song he had been commissioned to write for the African Cup of Nations football (soccer) match, “Soul Makossa” which ultimately marked the turning point in his career.

In 1973, He toured internationally with the American salsa band the Fania All Stars. Several years later, he released albums like Gone Clear (1980) and Ambassador (1980), Home Made (1978), featuring Nigerian and Ghanaian musicians, and Waka Juju (1982). Dibango also composed music for film and television.

In 1990, he published his autobiography, "Three Kilos of Coffee" (originally in French), with Danielle Rouard. Harbouring a deep and ongoing concern for the well-being of humanity, he often used his music and his influence to garner support for various humanitarian causes.

In 2004, In recognition of his contributions to the development of music as well as his cultivation of cross-cultural dialogue—particularly between Europe, Africa, and North America—through the arts, he was named the UNESCO Peace Artist of the Year.

On 24th March 2020, Dibango died after contracting COVID-19.
